p:slide.p:title: Sequences
p:slide.p: Sequences are one of the most significant changes between XSLT 1.0 and 2.0.
XSLT 1.0 had node sets and tree fragments. Both are subsumed into sequences in XSLT 2.0

p.strong: A sequence is an ordered group of nodes.

p:slide.p:title: Sequences (cont)
p:slide.p: The result of almost anything that generates content
They are not sets - the same element can occur many times

ul.li: Selecting nodes normally processes them in document order.
Sequences are in the order created

p:slide.p:title: Sequences are Ordered (cont)
p:slide.p: <xsl:apply-templates select="*"> or <xsl:apply-templates select="lastname|firstname"> would do the same.

p:slide.p:title: Sequences are Ordered (cont)
p:slide.p: Sequences can provide a simple solution to ordering.

p:slide.p:title: Sequences in Use
p:slide.p: Almost everything in XSLT 2.0 operates on or generates sequences
Templates generate sequences. This means we can generate sequences and assign them to a variable. Templates can generate multiple elements simply.
We apply templates to the selected sequence. This means we can apply templates to a variable holding a sequence.
We will discuss sequence functions later when we cover XPath 2 in detail
